metadata.title: Tab bars | Apple Developer Documentation
metadata.author: Apple Inc.
metadata.summary: Apple Human Interface Guidelines documentation for Tab bars, describing best practices for implementing tab bar navigation across iOS, iPadOS, macOS, tvOS, and visionOS platforms. The document covers design principles, platform-specific considerations, customization options, and developer resources.

content.text: Tab bars
A tab bar lets people navigate between top-level sections of your app.
Platforms

content.description: A stylized illustration showing a horizontal tab bar interface element. The tab bar appears to float above a coral/salmon colored gradient background. The tab bar contains four items labeled 'Tab1', 'Tab2', 'Tab3', and 'Tab4', each represented by a star icon. The first tab (Tab1) appears selected with a filled star icon, while the others show outline star icons. The tab bar has a translucent, frosted glass appearance (Liquid Glass effect) with rounded corners. The overall aesthetic is minimalist and modern, consistent with Apple's design language.
subjects: Four tab items with star icons
content.composition: Horizontal tab bar centered in frame, floating above gradient background
content.technicalDetails: Illustration demonstrating iOS/iPadOS tab bar with Liquid Glass design system
content.contextualRelevance: Hero image introducing the tab bar component and its visual appearance in the current Apple design system

content.text: Tab bars help people understand the different types of information or functionality that an app provides. They also let people quickly switch between sections of the view while preserving the current navigation state within each section.
Best practices

Use a tab bar to support navigation, not to provide actions. A tab bar lets people navigate among different sections of an app, like the Alarm, Stopwatch, and Timer tabs in the Clock app. If you need to provide controls that act on elements in the current view, use a toolbar instead.
content.strongText: Use a tab bar to support navigation, not to provide actions.

content.text: Make sure the tab bar is visible when people navigate to different sections of your app. If you hide the tab bar, people can forget which area of the app they're in. The exception is when a modal view covers the tab bar, because a modal is temporary and self-contained.
content.strongText: Make sure the tab bar is visible when people navigate to different sections of your app.

content.text: Use the appropriate number of tabs required to help people navigate your app. As a representation of your app's hierarchy, it's important to weigh the complexity of additional tabs against the need for people to frequently access each section; keep in mind that it's generally easier to navigate among fewer tabs. Where available, consider a sidebar or a tab bar that adapts to a sidebar as an alternative for an app with a complex information structure.
content.strongText: Use the appropriate number of tabs required to help people navigate your app.

content.text: Avoid overflow tabs. Depending on device size and orientation, the number of visible tabs can be smaller than the total number of tabs. If horizontal space limits the number of visible tabs, the trailing tab becomes a More tab in iOS and iPadOS, revealing the remaining items in a separate list. The More tab makes it harder for people to reach and notice content on tabs that are hidden, so limit scenarios in your app where this can happen.

Don't disable or hide tab bar buttons, even when their content is unavailable. Having tab bar buttons available in some cases but not others makes your app's interface appear unstable and unpredictable. If a section is empty, explain why its content is unavailable.
content.strongText: Don't disable or hide tab bar buttons, even when their content is unavailable.

content.text: Include tab labels to help with navigation. A tab label appears beneath or beside a tab bar icon, and can aid navigation by clearly describing the type of content or functionality the tab contains. Use single words whenever possible.
content.strongText: Include tab labels to help with navigation.

content.text: Consider using SF Symbols to provide familiar, scalable tab bar icons. When you use SF Symbols, tab bar icons automatically adapt to different contexts. For example, the tab bar can be regular or compact, depending on the device and orientation. Tab bar icons appear above tab labels in compact views, whereas in regular views, the icons and labels appear side by side. Prefer filled symbols or icons for consistency with the platform.
content.strongText: Consider using SF Symbols to provide familiar, scalable tab bar icons.

content.text: If you're creating custom tab bar icons, see Apple Design Resources for tab bar icon dimensions.

Use a badge to indicate that critical information is available. You can display a badge — a red oval containing white text and either a number or an exclamation point — on a tab to indicate that there's new or updated information in the section that warrants a person's attention. Reserve badges for critical information so you don't dilute their impact and meaning. For guidance, see Notifications.
content.strongText: Use a badge to indicate that critical information is available.

content.text: Platform considerations
No additional considerations for macOS. Not supported in watchOS.
iOS
A tab bar floats above content at the bottom of the screen. Its items rest on a Liquid Glass background that allows content beneath to peek through.

For tab bars with an attached accessory, like the MiniPlayer in Music, you can choose to minimize the tab bar and move the accessory inline with it when a person scrolls down. A person can exit the minimized state by tapping a tab or scrolling to the top of the view. For developer guidance, see TabBarMinimizeBehavior and UITabBarController.MinimizeBehavior.

content.description: Screenshot of an iPhone showing a tab bar in its expanded state with an attached accessory (like the MiniPlayer). The tab bar is positioned at the bottom of the screen with the accessory element visible above it. The interface shows the standard iOS tab bar appearance with Liquid Glass styling.
content.composition: iPhone screen mockup with tab bar and accessory at bottom
content.technicalDetails: iOS tab bar with attached accessory in expanded state
content.contextualRelevance: Demonstrates the expanded state of a tab bar with an attached accessory element

content.text: A tab bar with an attached accessory, expanded

content.description: Screenshot of an iPhone showing a tab bar in its minimized state with the attached accessory inline. The tab bar has collapsed to a more compact form with the accessory element now positioned inline with the tab bar items rather than above them. This demonstrates the space-saving minimized configuration.
content.composition: iPhone screen mockup with minimized tab bar at bottom
content.technicalDetails: iOS tab bar with attached accessory in minimized state
content.contextualRelevance: Demonstrates the minimized state of a tab bar with an attached accessory element moved inline

content.text: A tab bar with an attached accessory, minimized
A tab bar can include a distinct search item at the trailing end. For guidance, see Search fields.
iPadOS

The system displays a tab bar near the top of the screen. You can choose to have the tab bar appear as a fixed element, or with a button that converts it to a sidebar. For developer guidance, see tabBarOnly and sidebarAdaptable.

content.label: Note
content.text: To present a sidebar without the option to convert it to a tab bar, use a navigation split view instead of a tab view. For guidance, see Sidebars.

content.description: Screenshot of an iPad showing a tab bar positioned near the top of the screen. The tab bar displays horizontally with tab items arranged in a row. This represents the iPadOS 18 tab bar design where navigation appears at the top rather than the bottom of the screen.
content.composition: iPad screen mockup with tab bar at top
content.technicalDetails: iPadOS 18 tab bar in standard configuration
content.contextualRelevance: Shows iPadOS tab bar placement at top of screen

content.text: Tab bar

content.description: Screenshot of an iPad showing a sidebar configuration. The sidebar appears as a vertical navigation panel on the leading edge of the screen, displaying navigation items in a list format. This demonstrates the alternative to the tab bar that users can access through the adaptable tab bar feature in iPadOS 18.
content.composition: iPad screen mockup with sidebar on leading edge
content.technicalDetails: iPadOS 18 sidebar configuration (converted from tab bar)
content.contextualRelevance: Shows iPadOS sidebar as alternative to tab bar navigation

content.text: Sidebar

Prefer a tab bar for navigation. A tab bar provides access to the sections of your app that people use most. If your app is more complex, you can provide the option to convert the tab bar to a sidebar so people can access a wider set of navigation options.
content.strongText: Prefer a tab bar for navigation.

content.text: Let people customize the tab bar. In apps with a lot of sections that people might want to access, it can be useful to let people select items that they use frequently and add them to the tab bar, or remove items that they use less frequently. For example, in the Music app, a person can choose a favorite playlist to display in the tab bar. If you let people select their own tabs, aim for a default list of five or fewer to preserve continuity between compact and regular view sizes. For developer guidance, see TabViewCustomization and UITab.Placement.
content.strongText: Let people customize the tab bar.

content.text: tvOS
A tab bar is highly customizable. For example, you can:

items: Specify a tint, color, or image for the tab bar background
Choose a font for tab items, including a different font for the selected item
Specify tints for selected and unselected items
Add button icons, like settings and search

content.text: By default, a tab bar is translucent, and only the selected tab is opaque. When people use the remote to focus on the tab bar, the selected tab includes a drop shadow that emphasizes its selected state. The height of a tab bar is 68 points, and its top edge is 46 points from the top of the screen; you can't change either of these values.

If there are more items than can fit in the tab bar, the system truncates the rightmost item by applying a fade effect that begins at the right side of the tab bar. If there are enough items to cause scrolling, the system also applies a truncating fade effect that starts from the left side.

Be aware of tab bar scrolling behaviors. By default, people can scroll the tab bar offscreen when the current tab contains a single main view. You can see examples of this behavior in the Watch Now, Movies, TV Show, Sports, and Kids tabs in the TV app. The exception is when a screen contains a split view, such as the TV app's Library tab or an app's Settings screen. In this case, the tab bar remains pinned at the top of the view while people scroll the content within the primary and secondary panes of the split view. Regardless of a tab's contents, focus always returns to the tab bar at the top of the page when people press Menu on the remote.
content.strongText: Be aware of tab bar scrolling behaviors.

content.text: In a live-viewing app, organize tabs in a consistent way. For the best experience, organize content in live-streaming apps with tabs in the following order:
content.strongText: In a live-viewing app, organize tabs in a consistent way.

items: Cloud DVR or other recorded content

content.text: For additional guidance, see Live-viewing apps.
visionOS

In visionOS, a tab bar is always vertical, floating in a position that's fixed relative to the window's leading side. When people look at a tab bar, it automatically expands; to open a specific tab, people look at the tab and tap. While a tab bar is expanded, it can temporarily obscure the content behind it.

content.description: Video demonstration showing the visionOS tab bar interaction. The video shows a vertical tab bar on the leading edge of a window that expands when the user looks at it, revealing tab labels alongside the icons. The video demonstrates the eye-tracking interaction model where users look at a tab and tap to select it.
content.contextualRelevance: Demonstrates the unique interaction model for tab bars in visionOS spatial computing environment

content.text: Supply a symbol and a text label for each tab. A tab's symbol is always visible in the tab bar. When people look at the tab bar, the system reveals tab labels, too. Even though the tab bar expands, you need to keep tab labels short so people can read them at a glance.
content.strongText: Supply a symbol and a text label for each tab.

content.description: Screenshot showing a visionOS window with a collapsed vertical tab bar on the leading edge. The tab bar shows only icons (symbols) in a vertical arrangement, taking minimal horizontal space. The window displays content from an app (appears to be a nature/travel app showing 'GALAPAGOS' text and scenic imagery). The tab bar is in its default collapsed state, showing compact icon-only navigation.
content.composition: visionOS window with vertical tab bar on left edge, collapsed to show icons only
content.technicalDetails: visionOS tab bar in collapsed state showing only symbols
content.contextualRelevance: Shows the default collapsed state of visionOS tab bar with icon-only display

content.text: Collapsed

content.description: Screenshot showing a visionOS window with an expanded vertical tab bar on the leading edge. The tab bar has expanded to show both icons and text labels for each tab, taking more horizontal space. The same app content is visible, but the tab bar now displays full navigation labels alongside each symbol. This expanded state occurs when users look at the tab bar.
content.composition: visionOS window with vertical tab bar on left edge, expanded to show icons and labels
content.technicalDetails: visionOS tab bar in expanded state showing symbols and text labels
content.contextualRelevance: Shows the expanded state of visionOS tab bar when user looks at it, revealing text labels

content.text: Expanded

If it makes sense in your app, consider using a sidebar within a tab. If your app's hierarchy is deep, you might want to use a sidebar to support secondary navigation within a tab. If you do this, be sure to prevent selections in the sidebar from changing which tab is currently open.
content.strongText: If it makes sense in your app, consider using a sidebar within a tab.

pages.pageSummary: Complete Apple Human Interface Guidelines documentation page for Tab bars, covering best practices for tab bar navigation design, platform-specific implementations for iOS, iPadOS, tvOS, and visionOS, with detailed guidance on Liquid Glass styling, tab bar customization, sidebar adaptation, and accessibility considerations.

crossPageElements.runningHeaders: Apple Developer Documentation - Design - Human Interface Guidelines
crossPageElements.runningFooters: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

sections.title: Introduction
sections.summary: Introduces tab bars as a navigation component that helps users understand app structure and quickly switch between sections while preserving navigation state.

sections.title: Best practices
sections.summary: Nine key guidelines for implementing tab bars effectively: use for navigation not actions, keep visible during navigation, use appropriate number of tabs, avoid overflow, never disable tabs, include labels, use SF Symbols, reference Apple Design Resources for custom icons, and use badges for critical information.

sections.title: Platform considerations

subsections.title: iOS
subsections.summary: Tab bar floats at bottom with Liquid Glass background, supports attached accessories with minimize behavior, can include search item.

subsections.title: iPadOS
subsections.summary: Tab bar appears near top of screen, can be fixed or convert to sidebar, supports customization via TabViewCustomization and UITab.Placement.

subsections.title: tvOS
subsections.summary: Highly customizable tab bar with specific dimensions (68pt height, 46pt from top), supports scrolling behaviors, specific tab order recommended for live-viewing apps.

subsections.title: visionOS
subsections.summary: Vertical tab bar fixed to window's leading side, expands on gaze, requires both symbol and text label for each tab, can include sidebar within tabs.

sections.summary: Platform-specific implementations and considerations for tab bars across iOS, iPadOS, tvOS, and visionOS. Not supported on watchOS, no additional considerations for macOS.

sections.title: Resources

subsections.title: Related
subsections.summary: Links to related HIG articles: Tab views, Toolbars, Sidebars, Materials.

subsections.title: Developer documentation
subsections.summary: Links to SwiftUI (TabView, TabViewBottomAccessoryPlacement, tab navigation guide) and UIKit (UITabBar, iPad tab bar/sidebar guide) documentation.

subsections.title: Videos
subsections.summary: Links to WWDC videos: 'Get to know the new design system' and 'Elevate the design of your iPad app'.

sections.summary: Collection of related resources including HIG articles, developer documentation for SwiftUI and UIKit, and WWDC video sessions.

sections.title: Change log
sections.summary: Document revision history from June 2023 (visionOS guidance) through July 2025 (Liquid Glass guidance).

semanticStructure.documentFlow: The document begins with an introduction defining tab bars and their purpose, followed by comprehensive best practices applicable across all platforms. It then provides platform-specific guidance for each supported Apple platform (iOS, iPadOS, tvOS, visionOS), with detailed implementation notes and visual examples. The document concludes with resources including related documentation, developer references, videos, and a change log tracking document updates.

keyTerms.definition: A navigation component that lets people navigate between top-level sections of an app while preserving navigation state within each section
Apple's translucent material design system that allows content beneath UI elements to peek through
Apple's library of scalable, customizable symbols that automatically adapt to different contexts
A red oval containing white text (number or exclamation point) indicating critical information that warrants attention
A vertical navigation panel that can serve as an alternative to tab bars for apps with complex information structures
A system-generated tab in iOS/iPadOS that appears when there are more tabs than can fit, revealing remaining items in a separate list
SwiftUI API for controlling tab bar minimize behavior with attached accessories
UIKit API for controlling tab bar minimize behavior with attached accessories
SwiftUI option for displaying tab bar as a fixed element in iPadOS
SwiftUI option for tab bar that can convert to a sidebar in iPadOS
SwiftUI API for allowing users to customize tab bar content
UIKit API for tab placement and customization

keyFindings: Tab bars should be used exclusively for navigation, not for actions - use toolbars for actions
Tab bars should remain visible during navigation to help users maintain context; exception is modal views
Fewer tabs are generally easier to navigate; consider sidebars for complex app hierarchies
Never disable or hide tab bar buttons - if content is unavailable, explain why
Always include tab labels using single words when possible for clear navigation
Prefer filled SF Symbols for consistency with platform design
Badges should be reserved for truly critical information to maintain their impact
iOS tab bars use Liquid Glass background and support attached accessories with minimize behavior
iPadOS tab bars appear at top of screen and can adapt between tab bar and sidebar views
tvOS tab bars are 68 points tall, 46 points from top, and support extensive customization
visionOS tab bars are always vertical, expand on gaze, and require both symbol and text label
Default tab count should be five or fewer to preserve continuity between compact and regular views
For live-viewing apps on tvOS, organize tabs in order: Live content, Cloud DVR/recorded content, Other content

designDecisions.decision: Tab bar placement varies by platform
designDecisions.rationale: iOS places tab bar at bottom for thumb accessibility, iPadOS places at top for larger screen optimization, visionOS uses vertical placement for spatial interface

designDecisions.decision: Use Liquid Glass background on iOS
designDecisions.rationale: Allows content beneath to peek through while maintaining visual hierarchy and modern aesthetic

designDecisions.decision: Support tab bar to sidebar conversion on iPadOS
designDecisions.rationale: Provides flexibility for apps with complex navigation needs while maintaining simple default experience

designDecisions.decision: Vertical tab bar with gaze expansion on visionOS
designDecisions.rationale: Optimizes for spatial computing interaction model where eye tracking is primary input method
Users can prioritize frequently used sections while maintaining consistent default experience
